Posts.Content: At my last appointment with my urologist to review my most recent PSA reading (4.3), he was prepared to give me an enema, a dose of levaquin, and do the biopsy THEN ... provided I had not taken any blood thinners or anti-inflammatories in the last 10 days. I had, so we scheduled it for .... today.
Posts.Title: Getting Biopsy in Two Weeks

Posts.Title: Getting Biopsy in Two Weeks

Posts.Content: 6/11/12 Pre-biopsy consult today with two DREs, one by the urologist, the other by a 3rd year med student. Both agree: Prostate 30-35gms, otherwise smooth & normal. Doctor confirmed cancer a 'possible' explanation for PSA velocity, but would not say 'probable'. Does not rule out possibility of a negative biopsy, true or false. Must be off my daily dose of baby aspirin for 10 days before the biopsy.
Posts.Title: Biopsy ... no biopsy?

Posts.Title: Biopsy ... no biopsy?

Posts.Content: Age 62, feel great, no symptoms or family history of PC, no urologic or erectile problems. DRE 1 year ago found enlarged prostate consistent with my age, but otherwise normal. PSA climbed steadily from 2.2 in Jan '10 to 4.3 this month. Urologist wants to do biopsy now. Does this make sense? Do I have an overly aggressive doctor? Is there no intermediate step before jumping right into the biopsy?
Posts.Title: Biopsy ... no biopsy?

Posts.Title: Biopsy ... no biopsy?

Posts.Content: Thank you, all. I had pretty much decided to get the biopsy before posting ... just because that's who I am. Faced with a personal crisis like this, I have to know and I have to do something. But in this case I wanted to be sure I wasn't doing the wrong thing. This is the key ..... Originally Posted by Replicant Catalona and other influential doctors say that a rise of more 0.4 or more in one year is reason to suspect cancer. BPH (benign enlargement) can cause PSA to rise, but much more gradually than that. Prostatitis, on the other hand, causes much larger and sudden spikes (3.0 or greater rise in one year). So you don't fall into either category according to that thinking. Your PSA velocity is apparently too fast for BPH to be the cause, too slow for prostatitis. I have a strong 'feeling' it's cancer. But I have to know, and I have to do something. And the sooner the better.
